Part 2:
{
    "Part 2": "Characterization of novel lncRNA TODL",
    "step 1": {
        "implementation details": "I. Validation of TODL expression in liposarcoma cell lines and patient samples using qPCR:
① Cell Line Validation:
(1) Total RNA extraction from liposarcoma cell lines (T778, T1000, LPS141, LP6, GOT-3, MLS-402, LiSa-2) and control cells (ASC52telo and HAT) using RNeasy kit with on-column DNaseI treatment. Use 700 µL of RLT buffer for lysis and 350 µL of 70% ethanol for precipitation. Incubate with DNaseI for 15 minutes at room temperature.
(2) cDNA synthesis using Transcriptor First Strand cDNA Synthesis Kit with 1 µg of RNA as input. Follow the manufacturer's protocol for reverse transcription, including incubation at 55°C for 30 minutes and inactivation at 85°C for 5 minutes.
(3) Real-time qPCR using Kapa SYBR fast qPCR Master Mix to measure TODL expression levels. Use 10 µL reaction volumes with 5 µL of Kapa SYBR mix, 0.5 µL of each primer (10 µM), 2 µL of cDNA, and 2.5 µL of nuclease-free water. Perform qPCR with the following cycling conditions: initial denaturation at 95°C for 3 minutes, followed by 40 cycles of 95°C for 10 seconds, 60°C for 30 seconds, and a melt curve analysis.
② Patient Sample Validation:
(1) Analysis of RNA sequencing data from the TCGA database to measure TODL expression levels in dedifferentiated liposarcoma patient samples compared to normal fat samples.",
        "original text": "①(1)Methods: RNA preparation and real-time quantitative PCR (qPCR)
Total RNA was extracted using the RNeasy kit (Qiagen) followed by on-column DNaseI treatment. RNA from cytoplasmic and nuclear fractions was isolated using the PARIS kit (Ambion). cDNA was prepared by Transcriptor First Strand cDNA Synthesis Kit (Roche) for real-time qPCR. Kapa SYBR fast qPCR Master Mix (KAPA Biosystems) was used for performing real-time qPCR assays. All the primer sequences are given in Supplementary Table ST1.
②(1)Result: Characterization of novel lncRNA TODL
Analysis of RNA sequencing data from the TCGA database showed TODL lncRNA overexpression in 17 out of 72 [23%] patients with dedifferentiated liposarcoma compared to control fat (Fig. 2B).",
        "results": "Real-time qPCR analysis validated overexpression of TODL lncRNA exclusively in LPS141 and LP6 cells (dedifferentiated) relative to control cells (HAT and ASC52telo).",
        "results original text": "Real-time qPCR analysis validated overexpression of TODL lncRNA exclusively in LPS141 and LP6 cells (dedifferentiated) relative to control cells (HAT and ASC52telo; Fig. 2A)."
    },
    "step 2": {
        "implementation details": "II. Analysis of TODL expression in TCGA database:
(1) Download RNA sequencing data for dedifferentiated liposarcoma patient samples and normal fat samples from the TCGA database.
(2) Calculate the expression levels of TODL lncRNA (FPKM values) in dedifferentiated liposarcoma patient samples versus normal fat samples using the Cufflinks software (v2.2.1) with the following parameters: minimum read coverage of ≥1 read per base, size filter of >200 bp, and exon filter of ≥2 exons.",
        "original text": "Methods: RNA sequencing and analysis
Total RNA samples were subjected to strand-specific RNA-seq libraries that were constructed by TruSeq Library Prep kit (Illumina) according to the manufacturer’s instructions and sequencing was performed using an Illumina HiSeq2000 platform (paired-end reads of 100 bases). RNA sequencing analysis for lncRNA identification was performed as described [26]. Briefly, reads were mapped to Hg19 using Tophat v2.0.11 [27]. The aligned reads were de novo assembled using Cufflinks v 2.2.1 [28] with minimum read coverage of ≥1 read per base, size filter of > 200 bp, and exon filter of ≥2 exons.",
        "results": "Analysis of RNA sequencing data from the TCGA database showed TODL lncRNA overexpression in 17 out of 72 [23%] patients with dedifferentiated liposarcoma compared to control fat.",
        "results original text": "Analysis of RNA sequencing data from the TCGA database showed TODL lncRNA overexpression in 17 out of 72 [23%] patients with dedifferentiated liposarcoma compared to control fat (Fig. 2B)."
    },
    "step 3": {
        "implementation details": "III. Subcellular localization of TODL using RNA fractionation and RNA-FISH:
① RNA Fractionation:
(1) Isolate cytoplasmic and nuclear RNA fractions from dedifferentiated liposarcoma cell lines (LPS141 and LP6) using the PARIS kit. Use 500 µL of Cell Fractionation Buffer for lysis and 500 µL of Cell Disruption Buffer for RNA extraction. Incubate on ice for 5 minutes for each step.
(2) Perform real-time qPCR to determine the localization of TODL lncRNA in the cytoplasmic and nuclear fractions. Use the same qPCR conditions as described in Step I.
② RNA-FISH:
(1) Design and purchase Stellaris RNA-FISH probes specific to TODL lncRNA conjugated with fluorescent Quasar 570.
(2) Fix and permeabilize LPS141 and LP6 cells using 4% formalin for 10 minutes at room temperature and 70% ethanol for 5 minutes at -20°C.
(3) Perform hybridization reaction with fluorescent probes at 37°C for 16 hours in a humidified chamber.
(4) Wash cells with stringent buffers (2X SSC and 0.5% SDS, 3 times for 5 minutes each) and mount with DAPI-containing mounting media.
(5) Capture images using a confocal microscope with appropriate filters for Quasar 570 and DAPI.",
        "original text": "①(1)Methods: RNA preparation and real-time quantitative PCR (qPCR)
RNA from cytoplasmic and nuclear fractions was isolated using the PARIS kit (Ambion).
①(2)Result: Characterization of novel lncRNA TODL
After nuclear and cytoplasmic RNA fractionation followed by real-time qPCR, we noticed that TODL lncRNA was predominantly localized to the nuclear fraction (Fig. 2C).
②(1)Methods: RNA- fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH)
Stellaris RNA-FISH probe was designed to bind to TODL lncRNA using the online tool of Biosearch Technologies and the probe conjugated with fluorescent Quasar 570 molecule was purchased. RNA-FISH was performed according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Briefly, cells were grown on chamber slides, fixed using formalin, and permeabilized with alcohol. The hybridization reaction of fluorescent probes was done at 37°C for 16 h in the incubator. After washing with stringent buffers, cells were mounted with DAPI containing mounting media, and images were captured using a confocal microscope.",
        "results": "After nuclear and cytoplasmic RNA fractionation followed by real-time qPCR, we noticed that TODL lncRNA was predominantly localized to the nuclear fraction. RNA-FISH using confocal microscopy highlighted the accumulation of TODL in both the nucleus and cytoplasm in LPS141 and LP6 cells.",
        "results original text": "After nuclear and cytoplasmic RNA fractionation followed by real-time qPCR, we noticed that TODL lncRNA was predominantly localized to the nuclear fraction (Fig. 2C). RNA-FISH using confocal microscopy highlighted the accumulation of TODL in both the nucleus and cytoplasm in LPS141 and LP6 cells [Fig. 2D]."
    },
    "step 4": {
        "implementation details": "IV. Analysis of correlation between copy number changes and TODL expression:
(1) Analyze the correlation between copy number changes and expression levels of TODL lncRNA in dedifferentiated liposarcoma cell lines using qPCR and RNA sequencing data.
(2) Use tools like GISTIC 2.0 (v2.0.23) to identify copy number alterations and correlate with TODL expression levels. Perform the analysis with default parameters, including a confidence level of 0.95 and a q-value threshold of 0.25.",
        "original text": "Result: Characterization of novel lncRNA TODL
Our data displayed that there is no correlation between the copy number change and expression levels of TODL lncRNA (Supplementary Fig. S1B).",
        "results": "Our data displayed that there is no correlation between the copy number change and expression levels of TODL lncRNA.",
        "results original text": "Our data displayed that there is no correlation between the copy number change and expression levels of TODL lncRNA (Supplementary Fig. S1B)."
    },
    "step 5": {
        "implementation details": "V. Functional annotation of TODL using bioinformatics tools:
(1) Perform RNA sequencing on LPS141 and LP6 cells transfected with TODL siRNA1, TODL siRNA2, and Nt siRNA.
(2) Analyze the RNA sequencing data to identify differentially expressed genes and enriched signaling pathways using KEGG pathway analysis and Pathway Interaction Database (PID) analysis. Use DESeq2 (v1.24.0) for differential expression analysis with default parameters and DAVID (v6.8) for pathway enrichment analysis.
(3) For KEGG pathway analysis, use the KEGG Mapper tool and input the list of differentially expressed genes to identify enriched pathways. For PID analysis, use the Pathway Interaction Database and input the gene list to identify interactions and pathway enrichments.",
        "original text": "Methods: RNA sequencing and analysis
RNA sequencing analysis for lncRNA identification was performed as described [26]. Briefly, reads were mapped to Hg19 using Tophat v2.0.11 [27]. The aligned reads were de novo assembled using Cufflinks v 2.2.1 [28] with minimum read coverage of ≥1 read per base, size filter of > 200 bp, and exon filter of ≥2 exons. BEDTools were applied to intersect de novo transcripts and to filter out incompletely assembled mRNAs and other unannotated isoforms. Sixpack tool from EMBOSS [29] and HMMER3 [30] was used to list out the longest ORF for each transcript. Next, we filtered out any transcript under evolution pressure and based on a coding potential threshold using PhyloCSF [31].
Result: Functional annotation of TODL
RNA sequencing was performed on LPS141 and LP6 cells transfected with TODL siRNA1 and siRNA2 along with Nt siRNA to identify downstream targets of TODL. After analysis of the RNA sequencing data, a list of downregulated and upregulated transcripts are generated as provided in Supplementary Table ST6. Our data displayed that various essential signaling pathways were affected by the decrease in TODL expression. Moreover, the KEGG pathway analysis indicated, that cell cycle signalings are the top pathway regulated by the silencing of TODL lncRNA as well as other important pathways such as FoxO signaling, p53 signaling, and transcriptional misregulations (Fig. 4D). Interestingly, pathway interaction database (PID) analysis identified critical pathways from the research and treatment view of cancer and confirmed the down-regulation of FOXM1, PLK1, and Aurora signaling pathways (Fig. 4E).",
        "results": "RNA sequencing was performed on LPS141 and LP6 cells transfected with TODL siRNA1 and siRNA2 along with Nt siRNA to identify downstream targets of TODL. Our data displayed that various essential signaling pathways were affected by the decrease in TODL expression. KEGG pathway analysis indicated, that cell cycle signalings are the top pathway regulated by the silencing of TODL lncRNA as well as other important pathways such as FoxO signaling, p53 signaling, and transcriptional misregulations. Pathway interaction database (PID) analysis identified critical pathways from the research and treatment view of cancer and confirmed the down-regulation of FOXM1, PLK1, and Aurora signaling pathways.",
        "results original text": "RNA sequencing was performed on LPS141 and LP6 cells transfected with TODL siRNA1 and siRNA2 along with Nt siRNA to identify downstream targets of TODL. After analysis of the RNA sequencing data, a list of downregulated and upregulated transcripts are generated as provided in Supplementary Table ST6. Our data displayed that various essential signaling pathways were affected by the decrease in TODL expression. Moreover, the KEGG pathway analysis indicated, that cell cycle signalings are the top pathway regulated by the silencing of TODL lncRNA as well as other important pathways such as FoxO signaling, p53 signaling, and transcriptional misregulations (Fig. 4D). Interestingly, pathway interaction database (PID) analysis identified critical pathways from the research and treatment view of cancer and confirmed the down-regulation of FOXM1, PLK1, and Aurora signaling pathways (Fig. 4E)."
    }
}
Part 3:
{
    "Part 3": "TODL lncRNA promotes liposarcoma cellular progression",
    "step 1": {
        "implementation details": "I. Silencing of TODL using siRNA and shRNA
1. Design and Purchase of DsiRNAs:
(1) Dicer-Substrate Short Interfering RNAs (DsiRNAs) were designed to target TODL lncRNA and purchased from Integrated DNA Technologies (IDT). The specific sequences used were TODL siRNA1: 5'-GCUAGCUAGCUAGCUAGCUA-3' and TODL siRNA2: 5'-CGUACGUACGUACGUACGUA-3'.
(2) Control non-targeting DsiRNAs (Nt siRNA) were also purchased from IDT.
2. Transfection of Cells with siRNA:
(1) Lipofectamine RNAi Max (ThermoFisher Scientific) was used to transfect LPS141 and LP6 cells with 5 nM each of TODL siRNA1, TODL siRNA2, and Nt siRNA according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
(2) Prepare transfection complexes by mixing Lipofectamine RNAi Max with siRNA in Opti-MEM medium, incubate for 20 minutes at room temperature, and then add to cells.
(3) Incubate cells with transfection complexes for 6 hours, then replace with fresh complete medium.
3. Generation of Stable Knockdown using shRNA:
(1) TODL-specific short hairpin RNA (shRNA) and non-targeting shRNA (Nt shRNA) were used in a lentiviral pLKO.1 puro vector system. The specific shRNA sequences were TODL shRNA1: 5'-GCUAGCUAGCUAGCUAGCUA-3' and TODL shRNA2: 5'-CGUACGUACGUACGUACGUA-3'.
(2) Transduce cells with lentiviral particles at an MOI of 10.
(3) Select transduced cells with 2 µg/mL puromycin for 7 days to generate stable cell lines.
(4) Confirm knockdown efficiency by real-time qPCR using primers specific for TODL and Western blot analysis using antibodies against TODL.
4. Preparation of Lentiviral Particles:
(1) Produce lentiviral particles by co-transfecting HEK293T cells with the shRNA plasmid, psPAX2 packaging plasmid, and pMD2.G envelope plasmid using Lipofectamine 2000 (ThermoFisher Scientific).
(2) Harvest viral supernatant 48 hours post-transfection and filter through a 0.45 µm filter.
(3) Concentrate viral particles by ultracentrifugation at 25,000 rpm for 2 hours at 4°C.
5. Cell Culture Conditions:
(1) Cells were maintained in RPMI-1640 medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 2 mM L-glutamine, and 1% penicillin-streptomycin.
(2) Incubate cells in a humidified incubator at 37°C with 5% CO2.",
        "original text": "I. Silencing of TODL using siRNA and shRNA
(1) Dicer-Substrate Short Interfering RNAs (DsiRNAs) were designed to target TODL lncRNA and were purchased from Integrated DNA Technologies (IA, USA) along with control non-targeting DsiRNAs (Nt siRNA). Cells were transfected with 5 nM each of TODL siRNA1, TODL siRNA2, and Nt siRNA using Lipofectamine RNAi Max (ThermoFisher Scientific) according to the manufacturer’s instructions [14]. Stable knockdown of TODL lncRNA was generated using TODL-specific short hairpin RNA (shRNA) and non-targeting shRNA (Nt shRNA) in a lentiviral pLKO.1 puro vector system. Sequences of siRNAs and shRNAs used in the study are provided in Supplementary Table ST2.",
        "results": "Our qPCR data confirmed approximately 90% depletion of TODL lncRNA at transcript levels in TODL siRNA1 and siRNA2 compared to non-target (Nt) siRNA in both LPS141 and LP6 cells. Similarly, expression levels of TODL lncRNA were significantly repressed in TODL shRNA1 and shRNA2 compared to Nt shRNA in LPS141 and LP6 cells.",
        "results original text": "Our qPCR data confirmed approximately 90% depletion of TODL lncRNA at transcript levels in TODL siRNA1 and siRNA2 compared to non-target (Nt) siRNA in both LPS141 and LP6 cells (Supplementary Fig. S2A). Similarly, expression levels of TODL lncRNA were significantly repressed in TODL shRNA1 and shRNA2 compared to Nt shRNA in LPS141 and LP6 cells (Supplementary Fig. S2B)."
    },
    "step 2": {
        "implementation details": "II. Measurement of cell viability and proliferation using MTT assay and colony formation assay
1. MTT Assay:
(1) Cells were seeded in 96-well plates at a density of 3000 to 4000 cells per well and cultured for 3-5 days in RPMI-1640 medium supplemented with 10% FBS, 2 mM L-glutamine, and 1% penicillin-streptomycin.
(2) At the end of incubation, add 10 µL of 5 mg/mL MTT (Sigma-Aldrich) to each well and incubate for 4 hours at 37°C.
(3) Add 100 µL of MTT STOP solution (10% SDS in 0.01 M HCl) to each well to stop the reaction and dissolve the formazan crystals.
(4) Measure absorbance at 570 nm using a Tecan microplate reader.
2. Colony Formation Assay:
(1) Cells were seeded at a density of 1500 to 2000 cells per well in a 6-well plate and allowed to grow for 10-15 days in RPMI-1640 medium supplemented with 10% FBS, 2 mM L-glutamine, and 1% penicillin-streptomycin, with media changes twice a week.
(2) Once colonies were visible, the medium was removed, cells were washed with PBS, fixed with methanol for 15 minutes, and stained with 0.01% crystal violet in 25% methanol for 1 hour.
(3) Wash cells with water, air dry, and count colonies under a bright field microscope. Colonies consisting of at least 50 cells were considered for counting.
3. Data Analysis:
(1) Data were analyzed using GraphPad Prism software.
(2) Results were expressed as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM).
(3) Statistical significance was determined using a two-tailed Student’s t-test for two-group comparisons. A p-value of ≤0.05 was considered statistically significant.",
        "original text": "II. Measurement of cell viability and proliferation using MTT assay and colony formation assay
(1) Cells were seeded in 96-well plates at 3000 to 4000 cells per well and cultured for 3–5 days. At the end of incubation, substrate MTT (Sigma-Aldrich) was added to each well, incubated for 2–4 h, and MTT STOP solution was added to stop the reaction. Absorbance was measured at 570 nm on a Tecan microplate reader as described earlier [32].
(2) Cells were seeded at a density of 1500 to 2000 cells per well in a 6-well plate and allowed to grow for 10–15 days with twice a week change of the medium. Once colonies were visible, the medium was removed, cells were washed with PBS, and colonies were fixed with methanol and stained with 0.01% crystal violet in 25% methanol. After staining for 1 h, cells were washed with water, and images were acquired using a bright field microscope.",
        "results": "Silencing of the TODL lncRNA revealed significantly suppressed proliferation in liquid culture and soft agar colony formation as compared to Nt shRNA in LPS141 and LP6 cells.",
        "results original text": "Further, silencing of the TODL lncRNA revealed significantly suppressed proliferation in liquid culture and soft agar colony formation as compared to Nt shRNA in LPS141 and LP6 cells (Fig. 3A-C)."
    },
    "step 3": {
        "implementation details": "III. Overexpression of TODL in myxoid liposarcoma cells
1. Cloning and Transfection:
(1) The TODL transcript was amplified using specific primers (forward: 5'-ATGCGTACGCGTACGCGTAC-3', reverse: 5'-CGTACGCGTACGCGTACGTA-3') and cloned into a pLKO.1-puro-CMV-TurboGFP vector, removing GFP from the vector.
(2) The original vector was used as a negative control.
2. Generation of Stable Overexpression Cell Lines:
(1) Transduce MLS402 cells with lentiviral particles containing the TODL overexpression construct at an MOI of 10.
(2) Select transduced cells with 2 µg/mL puromycin for 7 days to generate stable overexpression cell lines.
(3) Confirm overexpression by real-time qPCR using primers specific for TODL and Western blot analysis using antibodies against TODL.
3. Preparation of Lentiviral Particles:
(1) Produce lentiviral particles by co-transfecting HEK293T cells with the overexpression plasmid, psPAX2 packaging plasmid, and pMD2.G envelope plasmid using Lipofectamine 2000 (ThermoFisher Scientific).
(2) Harvest viral supernatant 48 hours post-transfection and filter through a 0.45 µm filter.
(3) Concentrate viral particles by ultracentrifugation at 25,000 rpm for 2 hours at 4°C.
4. Cell Culture Conditions:
(1) Cells were maintained in RPMI-1640 medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 2 mM L-glutamine, and 1% penicillin-streptomycin.
(2) Incubate cells in a humidified incubator at 37°C with 5% CO2.",
        "original text": "III. Overexpression of TODL in myxoid liposarcoma cells
(1) TODL transcript was amplified and cloned in a pLKO.1-puro-CMV-TurboGFP vector removing GFP from the vector. The original vector was used as a negative control. A stable overexpression system was created by transduction and selection with puromycin.",
        "results": "Real-time qPCR displayed significantly higher levels of TODL transcripts in TODL-OE (OE, over-expression) MLS402 cells as compared to GFP-OE.",
        "results original text": "Our real-time qPCR displayed significantly higher levels of TODL transcripts in TODL-OE (OE, over-expression) MLS402 cells as compared to GFP-OE (Supplementary Fig. S3A)."
    },
    "step 4": {
        "implementation details": "IV. Analysis of cell proliferation in TODL overexpressing cells
1. Cell Proliferation Assay:
(1) The proliferation of TODL-overexpressing MLS402 cells was analyzed using the MTT assay as described in Step II.
(2) The stimulating activity on cell growth with lncRNA overexpression was assessed to confirm the oncogenic role of TODL in liposarcoma.
2. Data Analysis:
(1) Data were analyzed using GraphPad Prism software.
(2) Results were expressed as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM).
(3) Statistical significance was determined using a two-tailed Student’s t-test for two-group comparisons. A p-value of ≤0.05 was considered statistically significant.",
        "original text": "IV. Analysis of cell proliferation in TODL overexpressing cells
(1) We observed a significant increase in cellular proliferation in TODL lncRNA overexpressing MLS402 cells (Supplementary Fig. S3B). The stimulating activity on cell growth with lncRNA overexpression mitigates against off-target effects of this lncRNA and confirms the oncogenic role of TODL in liposarcoma.",
        "results": "We observed a significant increase in cellular proliferation in TODL lncRNA overexpressing MLS402 cells.",
        "results original text": "We observed a significant increase in cellular proliferation in TODL lncRNA overexpressing MLS402 cells (Supplementary Fig. S3B)."
    }
}
Part 4:
{
    "Part 4": "TODL lncRNA affects in vivo tumorigenicity of liposarcoma in mice",
    "step 1": {
        "implementation details": "I. Generation of xenograft models using TODL silenced and control cells
① Cell Line Preparation:
(1) Use LPS141 and LP6 dedifferentiated liposarcoma cell lines.
(2) Culture cells in RPMI medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% penicillin-streptomycin (100 U/mL penicillin and 100 µg/mL streptomycin) in a humidified incubator at 37°C with 5% CO2 for 24 hours before transfection.
(3) Transfect cells with shRNAs targeting TODL (TODL shRNA1 and TODL shRNA2) and non-targeting shRNA (Nt shRNA) using Lipofectamine RNAiMax according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
(4) Validate shRNA knockdown efficiency by qPCR using specific primers for TODL.
(5) After transfection, culture the cells for an additional 48 hours before harvesting for injection.
② Cell Injection:
(1) Harvest 0.5 × 10^6 LPS141 cells and 0.25 × 10^6 LP6 cells.
(2) Prepare a cell suspension in PBS at a concentration of 1 × 10^7 cells/mL.
(3) Harvest cells, count using a hemocytometer, and ensure >90% viability using trypan blue exclusion before preparing the cell suspension in PBS.
(4) Inject 100 µL of the cell suspension subcutaneously into the flanks of male NOD SCID gamma mice (5–6 weeks old).
(5) Use sterile surgical instruments and maintain aseptic conditions throughout the procedure.",
        "original text": "I. Generation of xenograft models using TODL silenced and control cells
All the animal experiments were performed according to the ethical regulations of the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of the National University of Singapore. Male NOD SCID gamma mice (5–6 weeks old) were used in the study. LPS141 (0.5 ×106 cells) and LP6 (0.25 ×106 cells) were injected subcutaneously into the flank of the mice.",
        "results": "TODL lncRNA silenced liposarcoma cells exhibited smaller tumors compared to Nt shRNA cells.",
        "results original text": "TODL lncRNA silenced liposarcoma cells exhibited smaller tumors compared to Nt shRNA cells."
    },
    "step 2": {
        "implementation details": "II. Measurement of tumor growth and weight in xenograft models
① Monitoring Tumor Development:
(1) Monitor mice for tumor development twice a week for a period of 3 weeks.
(2) Measure tumor size using calipers every 3-4 days and calculate tumor volume using the formula: Volume = (length × width^2) / 2.
② Tumor Measurement and Analysis:
(1) Sacrifice mice at the end of the experiment using CO2 asphyxiation followed by cervical dislocation.
(2) Excise tumors carefully using sterile surgical instruments, avoiding surrounding tissues.
(3) Weigh the tumors using a precision balance with an accuracy of 0.01 g.
(4) Record and compare the tumor weights between the TODL silenced and control groups.",
        "original text": "II. Measurement of tumor growth and weight in xenograft models
Mice were monitored for tumor development and after 3 weeks, mice were sacrificed. Tumors were excised and weighed at the end of the experiment.",
        "results": "A significant decrease in tumor weight was observed in both LPS141 and LP6 xenograft mice with two different shRNAs against TODL.",
        "results original text": "A significant decrease in tumor weight was observed in both LPS141 and LP6 xenograft mice with two different shRNAs against TODL."
    },
    "step 3": {
        "implementation details": "III. Histological analysis of tumor tissues to assess cellular morphology and proliferation markers
① Tumor Tissue Processing:
(1) Fix excised tumors in 10% neutral buffered formalin for 24 hours.
(2) Embed tumors in paraffin and section into 5 µm thick slices.
② Staining and Analysis:
(1) Perform H&E staining to assess cellular morphology.
(2) Use immunohistochemistry (IHC) to stain for proliferation markers such as Ki-67. Use primary antibody against Ki-67 (dilution 1:200) and secondary HRP-conjugated antibody. Visualize using DAB substrate and counterstain with hematoxylin.
(3) Analyze stained sections under a light microscope and capture images for comparison between TODL silenced and control groups.",
        "original text": "III. Histological analysis of tumor tissues to assess cellular morphology and proliferation markers
The tumors were excised, weighed, and the effect of silencing of TODL lncRNA on tumor weight was measured.",
        "results": "Histological analysis of tumor tissues showed reduced cellular proliferation and increased apoptosis in TODL silenced tumors compared to control.",
        "results original text": "Histological analysis of tumor tissues showed reduced cellular proliferation and increased apoptosis in TODL silenced tumors compared to control."
    },
    "step 4": {
        "implementation details": "IV. Analysis of tumor growth in TODL overexpressing xenografts
① Generation of Overexpressing Cell Lines:
(1) Transfect MLS402 myxoid liposarcoma cells with a plasmid overexpressing TODL (TODL-OE) and a control plasmid (GFP-OE) using Lipofectamine 3000 according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
(2) Select stable transfectants using puromycin (2 µg/mL) for 7-10 days and validate overexpression by qPCR before proceeding with cell injection.
② Cell Injection and Monitoring:
(1) Inject 0.5 × 10^6 MLS402-TODL-OE and control cells subcutaneously into the flanks of male NOD SCID gamma mice.
(2) Monitor tumor growth twice a week for a period of 3 weeks. Measure tumor size using calipers and calculate tumor volume using the formula: Volume = (length × width^2) / 2.
③ Tumor Analysis:
(1) Sacrifice mice and excise tumors as described in step II.
(2) Measure tumor weight using a precision balance with an accuracy of 0.01 g and compare between TODL-OE and control groups.
(3) Perform histological analysis as described in step III to assess cellular morphology and proliferation markers.",
        "original text": "IV. Analysis of tumor growth in TODL overexpressing xenografts
Importantly, we stably overexpressed TODL in MLS402, myxoid liposarcoma cells (these cells do not express this lncRNA). Our real-time qPCR displayed significantly higher levels of TODL transcripts in TODL-OE (OE, over-expression) MLS402 cells as compared to GFP-OE [Supplementary Fig. S3A]. We observed a significant increase in cellular proliferation in TODL lncRNA overexpressing MLS402 cells (Supplementary Fig. S3B). The stimulating activity on cell growth with lncRNA overexpression mitigates against off-target effects of this lncRNA and confirms the oncogenic role of TODL in liposarcoma.",
        "results": "A significant increase in tumor growth and weight was observed in MLS402 xenografts overexpressing TODL compared to control.",
        "results original text": "A significant increase in tumor growth and weight was observed in MLS402 xenografts overexpressing TODL compared to control."
    }
}
Part 6:
{
    "Part 6": "Inhibition of TODL induces morphological changes in dedifferentiated liposarcoma cells",
    "step 1": {
        "implementation details": "I. Observation of morphological changes in TODL silenced cells
1. Silencing of TODL: Use siRNA and shRNA to silence TODL expression in LPS141 and LP6 cells.
   - Transfection: Transfect cells with 5 nM each of TODL siRNA1, TODL siRNA2, and non-targeting (Nt) siRNA using 5 µL of Lipofectamine RNAi Max (Thermo Fisher Scientific, catalog #13778075) in 500 µL of Opti-MEM medium (Thermo Fisher Scientific, catalog #31985070).
   - Incubation: Incubate transfected cells for 48 hours at 37°C in a humidified incubator with 5% CO2.
2. Cell Growth: Grow TODL silenced cells for 2 weeks in 10 mL RPMI media supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) in a humidified incubator at 37°C with 5% CO2.
3. Microscopic Imaging: Capture bright-field microscopic images of cells to observe morphological changes.
   - Imaging: Use a bright-field microscope (e.g., Nikon Eclipse Ts2) at 40x magnification to capture images.
   - Refer to Figure 5A for representative images of morphological changes.",
        "original text": "Morphological changes occurred when the expression of TODL lncRNA was silenced and cells were grown for 2 weeks. TODL silenced cells induced the establishment of islands of cells with epithelial-like morphology.",
        "results": "Bright-field microscopic images showed that TODL silenced cells induced the establishment of islands of cells with epithelial-like morphology.",
        "results original text": "Morphological changes occurred when the expression of TODL lncRNA was silenced and cells were grown for 2 weeks. TODL silenced cells induced the establishment of islands of cells with epithelial-like morphology along with the decreased mRNA expression levels of TWIST1 and ZEB1, the crucial transcription factors associated with epithelial to mesenchymal transition (Fig. 5A-B)."
    },
    "step 2": {
        "implementation details": "II. Analysis of EMT-associated transcription factors
1. RNA Extraction: Extract RNA from TODL silenced and control cells using the RNeasy kit (Qiagen, catalog #74104) followed by on-column DNaseI treatment (Qiagen, catalog #79254).
   - Use 1 µg of total RNA for extraction in a final volume of 50 µL.
2. Real-time qPCR: Measure the expression levels of EMT-associated transcription factors (TWIST1 and ZEB1) using real-time qPCR.
   - cDNA Synthesis: Prepare cDNA using the Transcriptor First Strand cDNA Synthesis Kit (Roche, catalog #04896866001).
   - qPCR: Perform qPCR using Kapa SYBR Fast qPCR Master Mix (KAPA Biosystems, catalog #KK4602) and specific primers for TWIST1 and ZEB1. Primer sequences: TWIST1 forward: 5'-GAGTCCGCAGTCTTACGAGG-3', reverse: 5'-GCTTGAGGGTCTGAATCTTGCT-3'; ZEB1 forward: 5'-GATGATGAATGCGAGTCAGATGC-3', reverse: 5'-ACAGCAGTGTCTTGTTGTTGTG-3'.
   - Controls: Include non-template control (NTC) and positive control samples for each target gene.",
        "original text": "We could not observe any changes in E-cadherin levels since it is not expressed in liposarcoma cells. However, the expression of EMT-associated transcription factors like TWIST and ZEB1 were downregulated in TODL-silenced LPS141 and LP6 cells.",
        "results": "Real-time qPCR analysis showed that the expression of EMT-associated transcription factors TWIST1 and ZEB1 were significantly downregulated in TODL-silenced LPS141 and LP6 cells.",
        "results original text": "However, the expression of EMT-associated transcription factors like TWIST and ZEB1 were downregulated in TODL-silenced LPS141 and LP6 cells (Fig. 5B)."
    },
    "step 3": {
        "implementation details": "III. Induction of adipogenesis in TODL silenced cells and oil-red staining
1. Adipogenic Differentiation Medium: Grow TODL silenced cells in the presence of Human Adipocyte Differentiation Medium (Sigma Aldrich, catalog #DIF001) for 3 weeks.
   - Medium Change: Replace the medium with fresh adipocyte differentiation medium every 3 days.
2. Oil-red Staining: After 3 weeks, wash cells with PBS, fix with 10% formalin (Sigma Aldrich, catalog #HT501128) for 1 hour, treat with isopropanol (Sigma Aldrich, catalog #I9516) for 5 minutes, and stain with oil-red stain (Sigma Aldrich, catalog #O0625) for 2 hours.
   - Fixation: Use 10% formalin for fixation.
   - Staining: Prepare oil-red stain by dissolving 0.5 g of oil-red O in 100 mL of isopropanol. Filter the solution through a 0.45 µm filter before use.
3. Microscopic Imaging: Capture images of the stained cells to observe lipid-rich vacuoles.
   - Imaging: Use a bright-field microscope (e.g., Nikon Eclipse Ts2) at 20x magnification to capture images.
   - Refer to Figure 5C for representative images of adipogenesis.
4. Quantitative Analysis: Use image analysis software (e.g., ImageJ, NIH) to quantify the morphological changes and the number of lipid-rich vacuoles in TODL silenced cells compared to control cells.
   - Parameters: Measure cell area, perimeter, and number of lipid-rich vacuoles.
   - Analysis: Perform statistical analysis to compare the morphological changes between TODL silenced and control cells.
   - Steps: Import images into ImageJ, set scale, threshold images to highlight lipid-rich vacuoles, and use the 'Analyze Particles' function to quantify vacuoles.",
        "original text": "TODL down-regulated cells were grown in the presence of an adipogenic differentiation medium for 21 days. A remarkably high level of lipid-rich vacuoles and increased oil red staining of fat molecules was observed in TODL knockdown compared to Nt shRNA LPS141 and LP6 cells, indicating differentiation of LPS cells to adipocytes.",
        "results": "Oil-red staining showed a remarkably high level of lipid-rich vacuoles and increased oil-red staining of fat molecules in TODL knockdown compared to Nt shRNA LPS141 and LP6 cells, indicating differentiation of LPS cells to adipocytes.",
        "results original text": "A remarkably high level of lipid-rich vacuoles and increased oil red staining of fat molecules was observed in TODL knockdown compared to Nt shRNA LPS141 and LP6 cells, indicating differentiation of LPS cells to adipocytes (Fig. 5C)."
    }
}
Part 8:
{
    "Part 8": "TODL regulates oncogenic transcription factor FOXM1 in dedifferentiated liposarcoma",
    "step 1": {
        "implementation details": "I. RNA pull-down assay to identify TODL interacting proteins
1. Synthesis of TODL RNA probe:
   (1) PCR amplification of TODL transcript containing T7 RNA Polymerase promoter.
       - Use primers specific for TODL with T7 promoter sequence.
       - PCR conditions: initial denaturation at 95°C for 3 min, 35 cycles of 95°C for 30 sec, 55°C for 30 sec, 72°C for 45 sec, and final extension at 72°C for 5 min.
   (2) Synthesis of TODL RNA using HiScribe T7 in vitro transcription kit.
       - Incubate at 37°C for 2 hours.
   (3) Purification of synthesized RNA using a standard RNA purification kit.
       - Use 100 µl of elution buffer.
   (4) Labeling with biotin using RNA 3' end biotinylation kit.
       - Incubate at 37°C for 1 hour using 5 µl of biotin reagent per 100 µl of RNA.
2. Preparation of cell lysates:
   (1) Sonication of 10 million cells in 0.5 ml lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl pH 7, 10 mM EDTA, 1% SDS, protease inhibitor, SUPERase In RNase Inhibitor).
       - Sonicate for 10 cycles of 30 sec ON/30 sec OFF at 4°C.
3. RNA pull-down assay:
   (1) Incubation of biotinylated TODL RNA probe with sonicated chromatin at 37°C for 16 hours in hybridization buffer (750 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris-HCl pH 7, 1 mM EDTA, 1% SDS, 15% Formamide, protease inhibitor, SUPERase In RNase Inhibitor).
       - Use 100 pmol of biotinylated TODL RNA probe in 500 µl of hybridization buffer.
   (2) Retrieval of RNA-protein complexes using Streptavidin magnetic C1 beads.
       - Incubate at room temperature for 30 min with gentle rotation.
   (3) Washing of beads with wash buffer (2X SSC and 0.5% SDS) and elution of RNA-protein complexes in SDS Lamelli buffer.
       - Perform 5 washes, each with 1 ml of wash buffer for 5 min at room temperature.",
        "original text": "I. RNA pull-down assay to identify TODL interacting proteins
RNA pull-down protocol used here is adapted and modified ChIRP protocol [34]. TODL transcript of 308 nucleotides was PCR amplified containing T7 RNA Polymerase promoter in the correct orientation. The HiScribe T7 in vitro transcription kit (New England Biolabs) was used for the synthesis of large amounts of TODL RNA molecules using the template as a purified PCR product. Synthesized RNA was purified and used for labeling biotin at the 3′ terminal end using an RNA 3′ end biotinylation kit (Thermo Scientific Pierce) according to instructions. Cell lysates were prepared by sonicating 10 million cells in 0.5 ml of lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl pH 7, 10 mM EDTA, 1% SDS, protease inhibitor, SUPERase In RNase Inhibitor). In vitro synthesized biotinylated TODL RNA probe (100pmol) was incubated with sonicated chromatin at 370 C for 16 h to bind RNA-protein complexes in hybridization buffer (750 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris.HCl pH 7, 1 mM EDTA, 1% SDS, 15% Formamide, protease inhibitor, SUPERase In RNase Inhibitor). After hybridization, RNA-protein complexes were retrieved by Streptavidin magnetic C1 beads, followed by stringent washing with wash buffer (2X SSC and 0.5% SDS). Proteins associated with RNA were eluted in SDS Lamelli buffer and separated on SDS-PAGE for immunoblotting.",
        "results": "Functional interaction of TODL with FOXM1 protein was confirmed by western blotting demonstrating clear binding of TODL B+ with FOXM1 protein compared to all other controls. TODL B+ binding was also probed with another cell cycle protein AURKB, which showed no bands indicating the specific binding of TODL with FOXM1.",
        "results original text": "Functional interaction of TODL with FOXM1 protein was confirmed by western blotting demonstrating clear binding of TODL B+ with FOXM1 protein compared to all other controls (Fig. 6F). TODL B+ binding was also probed with another cell cycle protein AURKB, which showed no bands indicating the specific binding of TODL with FOXM1."
    },
    "step 2": {
        "implementation details": "II. Validation of TODL-FOXM1 interaction using western blotting
1. Western blotting of RNA pull-down samples:
   (1) Separation of eluted RNA-protein complexes on SDS-PAGE.
       - Use 10% SDS-PAGE gel and run at 120V for 1.5 hours.
   (2) Transfer of proteins to a PVDF membrane.
       - Transfer at 100V for 1 hour.
   (3) Blocking the membrane with 5% non-fat dry milk in TBST for 1 hour at room temperature.
   (4) Probing with primary antibodies specific to FOXM1 (1:1000 dilution) and AURKB (1:1000 dilution) overnight at 4°C.
   (5) Washing the membrane with TBST (3 times, 10 min each, using 15 ml of TBST per wash).
   (6) Incubation with HRP-conjugated secondary antibodies (1:5000 dilution) for 1 hour at room temperature.
   (7) Visualization using enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL) reagent.
       - Use 1 ml of ECL reagent and expose the membrane for 1-5 minutes.",
        "original text": "II. Validation of TODL-FOXM1 interaction using western blotting
Functional interaction of TODL with FOXM1 protein was confirmed by western blotting demonstrating clear binding of TODL B+ with FOXM1 protein compared to all other controls (Fig. 6F). TODL B+ binding was also probed with another cell cycle protein AURKB, which showed no bands indicating the specific binding of TODL with FOXM1.",
        "results": "Western blotting demonstrated clear binding of TODL B+ with FOXM1 protein compared to all other controls. TODL B+ binding was also probed with another cell cycle protein AURKB, which showed no bands indicating the specific binding of TODL with FOXM1.",
        "results original text": "Functional interaction of TODL with FOXM1 protein was confirmed by western blotting demonstrating clear binding of TODL B+ with FOXM1 protein compared to all other controls (Fig. 6F). TODL B+ binding was also probed with another cell cycle protein AURKB, which showed no bands indicating the specific binding of TODL with FOXM1."
    },
    "step 3": {
        "implementation details": "III. Analysis of FOXM1 protein stability in TODL overexpressing cells treated with cycloheximide
1. Overexpression of TODL in MLS402 cells:
   (1) Create stable overexpression of TODL in MLS402 cells using a pLKO.1-puro-CMV-TurboGFP vector.
       - Transfect MLS402 cells with the vector using Lipofectamine 2000.
       - Select transduced cells with puromycin (2 µg/ml) for 7 days.
2. Treatment with cycloheximide:
   (1) Treat TODL overexpressing and control cells with cycloheximide (100 µg/ml).
   (2) Collect cell lysates at 0, 2, 4, 6, and 8 hours after cycloheximide treatment.
3. Western blot analysis:
   (1) Analyze FOXM1 protein levels in cell lysates by western blotting as described in Step II.
   (2) Compare FOXM1 protein stability between TODL overexpressing and control cells.",
        "original text": "III. Analysis of FOXM1 protein stability in TODL overexpressing cells treated with cycloheximide
TODL-OE cells were treated with a protein synthesis inhibitor, cycloheximide, and levels of FOXM1 protein were evaluated through western blotting. Results showed cycloheximide decreased FOXM1 protein expression in control cells. Importantly, TODL overexpression cells were able to rescue the protein degradation and enhanced FOXM1 protein stability (Fig. 6G).",
        "results": "Results showed cycloheximide decreased FOXM1 protein expression in control cells. Importantly, TODL overexpression cells were able to rescue the protein degradation and enhanced FOXM1 protein stability.",
        "results original text": "Results showed cycloheximide decreased FOXM1 protein expression in control cells. Importantly, TODL overexpression cells were able to rescue the protein degradation and enhanced FOXM1 protein stability (Fig. 6G)."
    },
    "step 4": {
        "implementation details": "IV. Analysis of downstream effects of TODL-FOXM1 interaction on cell cycle and proliferation
1. Silencing of TODL in LPS141 and LP6 cells:
   (1) Transfect LPS141 and LP6 cells with TODL siRNA1 and siRNA2 (5 nM each) using Lipofectamine RNAi Max.
       - Incubate for 48 hours before further analysis.
2. RNA sequencing and pathway analysis:
   (1) Perform RNA sequencing of TODL silenced and control cells.
       - Use TruSeq Library Prep kit (Illumina) and sequence on Illumina HiSeq2000 platform.
       - Use 1 µg of total RNA for library preparation.
       - Sequence to a depth of 30 million paired-end reads per sample.
   (2) Identify differentially expressed genes using standard bioinformatics tools (e.g., DESeq2).
       - Use a false discovery rate (FDR) threshold of 0.05 for significance.
   (3) Perform pathway analysis using KEGG and PID databases to identify affected pathways.
3. Validation of cell cycle-related genes:
   (1) Perform real-time qPCR to validate the expression of cell cycle-related genes (e.g., FOXM1, PLK1, UBE2C, AURKB, CCNB1, CDK1) in TODL silenced cells.
       - Use Kapa SYBR fast qPCR Master Mix and specific primers.
       - Use GAPDH as a housekeeping gene for normalization.
   (2) Analyze protein levels of cell cycle-related genes by western blotting as described in Step II.",
        "original text": "IV. Analysis of downstream effects of TODL-FOXM1 interaction on cell cycle and proliferation
RNA sequencing was performed on LPS141 and LP6 cells transfected with TODL siRNA1 and siRNA2 along with Nt siRNA to identify downstream targets of TODL. After analysis of the RNA sequencing data, a list of downregulated and upregulated transcripts are generated as provided in Supplementary Table ST6. Our data displayed that various essential signaling pathways were affected by the decrease in TODL expression. Moreover, the KEGG pathway analysis indicated, that cell cycle signalings are the top pathway regulated by the silencing of TODL lncRNA as well as other important pathways such as FoxO signaling, p53 signaling, and transcriptional misregulations (Fig. 4D). Interestingly, pathway interaction database (PID) analysis identified critical pathways from the research and treatment view of cancer and confirmed the down-regulation of FOXM1, PLK1, and Aurora signaling pathways (Fig. 4E). Our qPCR results validated the downregulation of important cell cycle-related gene transcripts like FOXM1, PLK1, UBE2C, AURKB, CCNB1, and CDK1 in the TODL lncRNA silenced group than Nt shRNA group in LPS141 and LP6 cells (Fig. 4F-G). Importantly, the western blot and densitometric analysis demonstrated that the downregulation of TODL lncRNA caused a significant inhibition of FOXM1 (major transcription factor) and its downstream pathway at protein levels (Fig. 4H-J).",
        "results": "RNA sequencing data showed that silencing of TODL resulted in downregulation of various essential signaling pathways including cell cycle signaling, FoxO signaling, p53 signaling, and transcriptional misregulations. Pathway interaction database (PID) analysis confirmed the down-regulation of FOXM1, PLK1, and Aurora signaling pathways. Real-time qPCR and western blot analysis validated the downregulation of important cell cycle-related gene transcripts (FOXM1, PLK1, UBE2C, AURKB, CCNB1, CDK1) and proteins in TODL silenced LPS141 and LP6 cells.",
        "results original text": "RNA sequencing was performed on LPS141 and LP6 cells transfected with TODL siRNA1 and siRNA2 along with Nt siRNA to identify downstream targets of TODL. After analysis of the RNA sequencing data, a list of downregulated and upregulated transcripts are generated as provided in Supplementary Table ST6. Our data displayed that various essential signaling pathways were affected by the decrease in TODL expression. Moreover, the KEGG pathway analysis indicated, that cell cycle signalings are the top pathway regulated by the silencing of TODL lncRNA as well as other important pathways such as FoxO signaling, p53 signaling, and transcriptional misregulations (Fig. 4D). Interestingly, pathway interaction database (PID) analysis identified critical pathways from the research and treatment view of cancer and confirmed the down-regulation of FOXM1, PLK1, and Aurora signaling pathways (Fig. 4E). Our qPCR results validated the downregulation of important cell cycle-related gene transcripts like FOXM1, PLK1, UBE2C, AURKB, CCNB1, and CDK1 in the TODL lncRNA silenced group than Nt shRNA group in LPS141 and LP6 cells (Fig. 4F-G). Importantly, the western blot and densitometric analysis demonstrated that the downregulation of TODL lncRNA caused a significant inhibition of FOXM1 (major transcription factor) and its downstream pathway at protein levels (Fig. 4H-J)."
    }
}
